end-date.help-text: Leave this field blank, if still present
end-date.label: End Date

tooltip.delete-item: Are you sure you want to delete this item? This is an irreversible action.

tooltips.delete: Are you sure you want to delete this resume? This is an irreversible action.
tooltips.share-link: You need to change the visibility of your resume to public to make it visible to others.

json.secondary: Download a JSON version of your resume that can be imported back into TivlotCV.

loading.secondary: Please wait as your PDF gets generated, this may take upto 15 seconds.

normal.secondary: Download a PDF of your resume that you can print and send out to your dream job. This file cannot be imported back for further editing.

bugs-features.body: Something stopping you from making a resume? Or do you have an amazing idea to add? Raise an issue on GitHub to get started.
bugs-features.heading: Bugs? Feature Requests?

donate.body: If you liked using TivlotCV, please consider donating as much as you can to the cause of keeping the app up and running, without ads and free forever.
donate.heading: Donate to TivlotCV

date.secondary: Date format to use across the app

language.secondary: Display language to use across the app

break-line.secondary: Show a line on all pages to mark the height of an A4 page

orientation.disabled: Has no effect when there is only one page
orientation.secondary: Whether to display pages horizontally or vertically

reset.secondary: Made too many mistakes? Click here to reset all changes and start from scratch. Be careful, this action cannot be reversed.

sample.secondary: Not sure where to begin? Click here to load some sample data to see how a complete resume looks like.

visibility.subtitle: Allow anyone with a link to view your resume
visibility.title: Public

gradient_visibility.disabled: This resume template has no gradient
gradient_visibility.subtitle: Add a gradient to your resume
gradient_visibility.title: Gradient

shared.intro: Catch the reader's eye using the following ways:

li:
The goal is to keep the CV concise.
Always aim for 1 page, especially if you have no work experience relevant to the position you are applying for, but no more than 2 pages.

Carefully proofread your CV for spelling and grammar errors. Even small mistakes can be a red flag to potential employers, so it's important to take the time to ensure that your CV is error-free.
Download for FREE the <1>Grammarly Chrome Extension</1> to check your grammar, spelling, and punctuation in English.

website.intro: Once you've finished preparing your CV, you can take the way you present yourself to the next level by building a website.
li: Easy to use with ready and unique templates for **free!!!**
The goal is to stand out and show that you put in the extra effort.

summary.intro: This is the first section and sometimes the only section that recruiters will read, so make sure to write the most important and relevant qualifications for the position you are aiming for.
li:
Use our examples below and start editing
(pay attention to the structure and the use of high-value adjectives and action-oriented words).
This is your time to convince the hiring manager, you have the relevant values that will help the company reach its goals, so don't be afraid to brag!
generic: Second-year [Degree Type] student with a proven track record of success, work, and extracurricular activities. Highly motivated, organized, and proactive with excellent communication, problem-solving, and attentions to detail. Looking to leverage my skills and knowledge to make a positive impact in a professional environment.

Results-driven [Profession] with good technical skills, firm grasp of business needs and understanding of user requirements gathering. Assesses risks, troubleshoots problems and conducts tests. Excellent communication and planning abilities.

A highly creative [Profession] with over **2 years** of experience in [Industry]. Knowledgeable in [technologies, fields, etc]. Skilled in working under pressure and adapting to new situations and challenges to best **enhance** the organizational brand.

work.intro: If you have no relevant work experience as an employee or a freelancer, you need to write about a position you worked in and try to find parallel lines between it and the position you are aiming for. (Go to the 'Projects' section and treat each project as if it were work experience).
li-generic: Start with your most recent work experience.
li-description: Write in a concise and clear way, minimum 3 sentences that present your work and contribution.
Be prepared to elaborate on each sentence orally, because professional interviewers like to dive deep into those statements.

Open each of your bullet points with the following action-oriented verbs:
Led, Executed, Improved, Researched, Administered, Collaborated, Presented, Developed, Facilitated, Analyzed, Implemented, Managed, Coordinated, Optimized, Automated, Resolved, Achieved, Streamlined, Produced, Consolidated, Pioneered, Supervised, Disseminated, Trained, Mentored, Negotiated, Assessed, ...
Try to write at least one case where you did something extraordinary and what it improved/how it affected (put it at the top of the list!).

li-generic: If you don't have relevant work experience, take your best project and treat it as if it were work experience and place it above the 'Work Experience' section, this way you will show hiring managers willingness and readiness for the job.

If you have relevant work experience, there is no need to use this section.
Mention the project only if it shows you in a very positive light and place it under the 'Work Experience' section.
li-description: Describe in a concise and clear way your responsibilities and achievements while highlighting the skills you have developed.

Open each of your bullet points with the following action-oriented verbs:
Led, Executed, Improved, Researched, Administered, Collaborated, Presented, Developed, Facilitated, Analyzed, Implemented, Managed, Coordinated, Optimized, Automated, Resolved, Achieved, Streamlined, Produced, Consolidated, Pioneered, Supervised, Disseminated, Trained, Mentored, Negotiated, Assessed, ...
Be prepared to elaborate on each sentence orally, because professional interviewers like to dive deep into those statements.

li-generic: Mention the volunteering only if it presents you in a very positive light or is relevant to the position you are applying for (for example: contribution to an open source project), and place it in the 'Work Experience' section.
li-description: Describe in a concise and clear way your responsibilities and achievements while highlighting the skills you have developed.

Open each of your bullet points with the following action-oriented verbs:
Contributed, Assisted, Collaborated, Coordinated, Fundraised, Led, Mentored, Organized, Participated, Planned, Recruited, Tutored, ...

li-generic: Don't list every award you've ever received, be concise and focus on the most relevant and impressive ones.
li-description: Open each sentence with action-oriented verbs to describe your achievement, such as Won, Received, Achieved, Earned, Honored, Recognized, Selected, Presented, Awarded, etc.

li-generic: Only include certifications that are directly relevant to the job you are applying for or that demonstrate your expertise in a specific area.
If you have no relevant work experience, place this section below the 'Education' section.
List the most relevant or prestigious ones first.
Don't forget to include any relevant licenses or accreditations, such as a professional license or a teaching certification.
li-description: Include a description only if the certificate is not widely known or if it demonstrates a specific skill or area of knowledge.

li: If high school is the highest form of education you have, list it.
If you received any honors or awards during your studies, be sure to include them in this section.
If you took any courses that are particularly relevant to the job you are applying for, consider mentioning them.
There is a separate section below for all your Certifications and training programs, so don't include them here.
Before you start preparing your CV, collect several job descriptions and use them as a guideline.
After you have finished preparing your CV, click on the 'Duplicate' option and start including keywords from the job description in the company you are aiming for.
addResume.closure: According to studies, hiring managers will rate your CV higher if you make the necessary adjustments according to the job description.

li: Add only relevant links to your position.
Hiring managers can easily find all your other social networks, so clean them from anything that could make you look bad.
Community that allows employers and employees to contact each other directly, it is a great opportunity to surround yourself with people in your field.
List languages in order of proficiency, with your strongest language first.
If you have strong language skills that are relevant to the job you are applying for, mention them in the 'Summary' at the top of your CV.
If you have used your language skills in a professional setting, highlight this information in your 'Work Experience' section.

skills.intro:
Choose skills that are relevant to the job you are applying for.
For example, if you are applying for a job as a software developer, make sure to include your programming skills.
li: List skills in order of proficiency, with your strongest skill first (start with the technical type).
Try to list up to 10 skills in total from the 2 types combined.
If you have used your skills in a professional setting, highlight this information in your 'Work Experience' section.

reference.intro: This section is not mandatory, although its presence strengthens the overall visibility of your CV.
li: List (up to 2) relevant references for the position.
